item.title: PHP Gotcha: Using php://temp
item.description: Just a quicky post, that I hope will save someone (or myself) some head-scratching later. TLDR: Whenever you fopen('php://temp', $mode) you get a new file. I found this out when exporting some data from the DB to a spreadsheet/CSV. I was using Yectep\PhpSpreadsheetBundle\Factory (a Symfony bundle around phpoffice/phpspreadsheet) which had a handy method to save the file: $writer = $this->spreadsheetFactory->createWriter($spreadsheet, '.csv'); $writer->save('php://temp'); From there I would read it back, and upload it to a cloudfiles storage account using FlySystem:
